scene.title: SCENE I. Before Alexandria. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MECAENAS, with his Army; OCTAVIUS CAESAR reading a letter

speech.speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
speech.line: He calls me boy; and chides, as he had power
To beat me out of Egypt; my messenger
He hath whipp'd with rods; dares me to personal combat,
Caesar to Antony: let the old ruffian know
I have many other ways to die; meantime
Laugh at his challenge.

speech.speaker: MECAENAS
speech.line: Caesar must think,
When one so great begins to rage, he's hunted
Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now
Make boot of his distraction: never anger
Made good guard for itself.

speech.speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
speech.line: Let our best heads
Know, that to-morrow the last of many battles
We mean to fight: within our files there are,
Of those that served Mark Antony but late,
Enough to fetch him in. See it done:
And feast the army; we have store to do't,
And they have earn'd the waste. Poor Antony!

scene-body.stagedir: Enter MARK ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS, ALEXAS, with others

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: He will not fight with me, Domitius.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Why should he not?

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
He is twenty men to one.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: To-morrow, soldier,
By sea and land I'll fight: or I will live,
Or bathe my dying honour in the blood
Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: I'll strike, and cry 'Take all.'

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Well said; come on.
Call forth my household servants: let's to-night
Be bounteous at our meal.
Give me thy hand,
Thou hast been rightly honest;--so hast thou;--
Thou,--and thou,--and thou:--you have served me well,
And kings have been your fellows.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS What means this?

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: Aside to CLEOPATRA 'Tis one of those odd
tricks which sorrow shoots
Out of the mind.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: And thou art honest too.
I wish I could be made so many men,
And all of you clapp'd up together in
An Antony, that I might do you service
So good as you have done.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: The gods forbid!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Well, my good fellows, wait on me to-night:
Scant not my cups; and make as much of me
As when mine empire was your fellow too,
And suffer'd my command.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS What does he mean?

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: Aside to CLEOPATRA To make his followers weep.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Tend me to-night;
May be it is the period of your duty:
Haply you shall not see me more; or if,
A mangled shadow: perchance to-morrow
You'll serve another master. I look on you
As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,
I turn you not away; but, like a master
Married to your good service, stay till death:
Tend me to-night two hours, I ask no more,
And the gods yield you for't!

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: What mean you, sir,
To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep;
And I, an ass, am onion-eyed: for shame,
Transform us not to women.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Ho, ho, ho!
Now the witch take me, if I meant it thus!
Grace grow where those drops fall!
My hearty friends,
You take me in too dolorous a sense;
For I spake to you for your comfort; did desire you
To burn this night with torches: know, my hearts,
I hope well of to-morrow; and will lead you
Where rather I'll expect victorious life
Than death and honour. Let's to supper, come,
And drown consideration.

scene.title: SCENE III. The same. Before the palace.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter two Soldiers to their guard

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Brother, good night: to-morrow is the day.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: It will determine one way: fare you well.
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Nothing. What news?

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Belike 'tis but a rumour. Good night to you.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Well, sir, good night.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Soldiers, have careful watch.

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: And you. Good night, good night.

scene-body.stagedir: They place themselves in every corner of the stage

speech.speaker: Fourth Soldier
speech.line: Here we: and if to-morrow
Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope
Our landmen will stand up.

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: 'Tis a brave army,
And full of purpose.

scene-body.stagedir: Music of the hautboys as under the stage

speech.speaker: Fourth Soldier
speech.line: Peace! what noise?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: List, list!

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Hark!

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Music i' the air.

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: Under the earth.

speech.speaker: Fourth Soldier
speech.line: It signs well, does it not?

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Peace, I say!
What should this mean?

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: 'Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony loved,
Now leaves him.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Walk; let's see if other watchmen
Do hear what we do?

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: How now, masters!

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Speaking together How now!
How now! do you hear this?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Ay; is't not strange?

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: Do you hear, masters? do you hear?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter;
Let's see how it will give off.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Content. 'Tis strange.

scene.title: SCENE IV. The same. A room in the palace.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter MARK ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and others attending

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Eros! mine armour, Eros!

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Sleep a little.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: No, my chuck. Eros, come; mine armour, Eros!
Come good fellow, put mine iron on:
If fortune be not ours to-day, it is
Because we brave her: come.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Nay, I'll help too.
What's this for?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Ah, let be, let be! thou art
The armourer of my heart: false, false; this, this.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Sooth, la, I'll help: thus it must be.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Well, well;
We shall thrive now. Seest thou, my good fellow?
Go put on thy defences.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Briefly, sir.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Is not this buckled well?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Rarely, rarely:
He that unbuckles this, till we do please
To daff't for our repose, shall hear a storm.
Thou fumblest, Eros; and my queen's a squire
More tight at this than thou: dispatch. O love,
That thou couldst see my wars to-day, and knew'st
The royal occupation! thou shouldst see
A workman in't.
Good morrow to thee; welcome:
Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge:
To business that we love we rise betime,
And go to't with delight.

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: A thousand, sir,
Early though't be, have on their riveted trim,
And at the port expect you.

speech.speaker: Captain
speech.line: The morn is fair. Good morrow, general.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Good morrow, general.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: 'Tis well blown, lads:
This morning, like the spirit of a youth
That means to be of note, begins betimes.
So, so; come, give me that: this way; well said.
Fare thee well, dame, whate'er becomes of me:
This is a soldier's kiss: rebukeable
And worthy shameful cheque it were, to stand
On more mechanic compliment; I'll leave thee
Now, like a man of steel. You that will fight,
Follow me close; I'll bring you to't. Adieu.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt MARK ANTONY, EROS, Captains, and Soldiers

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: Please you, retire to your chamber.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Lead me.
He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might
Determine this great war in single fight!
Then Antony,--but now--Well, on.

scene.title: SCENE V. Alexandria. MARK ANTONY's camp.

scene-body.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter MARK ANTONY and EROS; a Soldier meeting them

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevail'd
To make me fight at land!

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: Hadst thou done so,
The kings that have revolted, and the soldier
That has this morning left thee, would have still
Follow'd thy heels.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Who's gone this morning?

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: Who!
One ever near thee: call for Enobarbus,
He shall not hear thee; or from Caesar's camp
Say 'I am none of thine.'

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: What say'st thou?

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: Sir,
He is with Caesar.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Sir, his chests and treasure
He has not with him.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Is he gone?

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: Most certain.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Go, Eros, send his treasure after; do it;
Detain no jot, I charge thee: write to him--
I will subscribe--gentle adieus and greetings;
Say that I wish he never find more cause
To change a master. O, my fortunes have
Corrupted honest men! Dispatch.--Enobarbus!

scene.title: SCENE VI. Alexandria. OCTAVIUS CAESAR's camp.

scene-body.stagedir: Flourish. Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, AGRIPPA, with DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, and others

speech.speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
speech.line: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight:
Our will is Antony be took alive;
Make it so known.

speech.speaker: AGRIPPA
speech.line: Caesar, I shall.

speech.speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
speech.line: The time of universal peace is near:
Prove this a prosperous day, the three-nook'd world
Shall bear the olive freely.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: Antony
Is come into the field.

speech.speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
speech.line: Go charge Agrippa
Plant those that have revolted in the van,
That Antony may seem to spend his fury
Upon himself.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: Alexas did revolt; and went to Jewry on
Affairs of Antony; there did persuade
Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar,
And leave his master Antony: for this pains
Caesar hath hang'd him. Canidius and the rest
That fell away have entertainment, but
No honourable trust. I have done ill;
Of which I do accuse myself so sorely,
That I will joy no more.

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: Enobarbus, Antony
Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with
His bounty overplus: the messenger
Came on my guard; and at thy tent is now
Unloading of his mules.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: I give it you.

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: Mock not, Enobarbus.
I tell you true: best you safed the bringer
Out of the host; I must attend mine office,
Or would have done't myself. Your emperor
Continues still a Jove.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: I am alone the villain of the earth,
And feel I am so most. O Antony,
Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid
My better service, when my turpitude
Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart:
If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean
Shall outstrike thought: but thought will do't, I feel.
I fight against thee! No: I will go seek
Some ditch wherein to die; the foul'st best fits
My latter part of life.

scene.title: SCENE VII. Field of battle between the camps.

scene-body.stagedir: Alarum. Drums and trumpets. Enter AGRIPPA and others

speech.speaker: AGRIPPA
speech.line: Retire, we have engaged ourselves too far:
Caesar himself has work, and our oppression
Exceeds what we expected.

scene-body.stagedir: Alarums. Enter MARK ANTONY and SCARUS wounded

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: O my brave emperor, this is fought indeed!
Had we done so at first, we had droven them home
With clouts about their heads.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Thou bleed'st apace.

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: I had a wound here that was like a T,
But now 'tis made an H.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: They do retire.

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: We'll beat 'em into bench-holes: I have yet
Room for six scotches more.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves
For a fair victory.

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: Let us score their backs,
And snatch 'em up, as we take hares, behind:
'Tis sport to maul a runner.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: I will reward thee
Once for thy spritely comfort, and ten-fold
For thy good valour. Come thee on.

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: I'll halt after.

scene.title: SCENE VIII. Under the walls of Alexandria.

scene-body.stagedir: Alarum. Enter MARK ANTONY, in a march; SCARUS, with others

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: We have beat him to his camp: run one before,
And let the queen know of our gests. To-morrow,
Before the sun shall see 's, we'll spill the blood
That has to-day escaped. I thank you all;
For doughty-handed are you, and have fought
Not as you served the cause, but as 't had been
Each man's like mine; you have shown all Hectors.
Enter the city, clip your wives, your friends,
Tell them your feats; whilst they with joyful tears
Wash the congealment from your wounds, and kiss
The honour'd gashes whole.
Give me thy hand
To this great fairy I'll commend thy acts,
Make her thanks bless thee.
O thou day o' the world,
Chain mine arm'd neck; leap thou, attire and all,
Through proof of harness to my heart, and there
Ride on the pants triumphing!

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Lord of lords!
O infinite virtue, comest thou smiling from
The world's great snare uncaught?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: My nightingale,
We have beat them to their beds. What, girl!
though grey
Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha' we
A brain that nourishes our nerves, and can
Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man;
Commend unto his lips thy favouring hand:
Kiss it, my warrior: he hath fought to-day
As if a god, in hate of mankind, had
Destroy'd in such a shape.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: I'll give thee, friend,
An armour all of gold; it was a king's.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled
Like holy Phoebus' car. Give me thy hand:
Through Alexandria make a jolly march;
Bear our hack'd targets like the men that owe them:
Had our great palace the capacity
To camp this host, we all would sup together,
And drink carouses to the next day's fate,
Which promises royal peril. Trumpeters,
With brazen din blast you the city's ear;
Make mingle with rattling tabourines;
That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together,
Applauding our approach.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: If we be not relieved within this hour,
We must return to the court of guard: the night
Is shiny; and they say we shall embattle
By the second hour i' the morn.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: This last day was
A shrewd one to's.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: O, bear me witness, night,--

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: What man is this?

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Stand close, and list him.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: Be witness to me, O thou blessed moon,
When men revolted shall upon record
Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did
Before thy face repent!

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Enobarbus!

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: Peace!
Hark further.

speech.speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
speech.line: O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,
The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me,
That life, a very rebel to my will,
May hang no longer on me: throw my heart
Against the flint and hardness of my fault:
Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder,
And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony,
Nobler than my revolt is infamous,
Forgive me in thine own particular;
But let the world rank me in register
A master-leaver and a fugitive:
O Antony! O Antony!

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Let's speak To him.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Let's hear him, for the things he speaks
May concern Caesar.

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: Let's do so. But he sleeps.

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: Swoons rather; for so bad a prayer as his
Was never yet for sleep.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Go we to him.

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: Awake, sir, awake; speak to us.

speech.speaker: Second Soldier
speech.line: Hear you, sir?

speech.speaker: First Soldier
speech.line: The hand of death hath raught him.
Hark! the drums
Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him
To the court of guard; he is of note: our hour
Is fully out.

speech.speaker: Third Soldier
speech.line: Come on, then;
He may recover yet.

scene.title: SCENE X. Between the two camps.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter MARK ANTONY and SCARUS, with their Army

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Their preparation is to-day by sea;
We please them not by land.

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: For both, my lord.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: I would they'ld fight i' the fire or i' the air;
We'ld fight there too. But this it is; our foot
Upon the hills adjoining to the city
Shall stay with us: order for sea is given;
They have put forth the haven
Where their appointment we may best discover,
And look on their endeavour.

scene.title: SCENE XI. Another part of the same.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, and his Army

speech.speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
speech.line: But being charged, we will be still by land,
Which, as I take't, we shall; for his best force
Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales,
And hold our best advantage.

scene.title: SCENE XII. Another part of the same.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Yet they are not join'd: where yond pine
does stand,
I shall discover all: I'll bring thee word
Straight, how 'tis like to go.

speech.speaker: SCARUS
speech.line: Swallows have built
In Cleopatra's sails their nests: the augurers
Say they know not, they cannot tell; look grimly,
And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony
Is valiant, and dejected; and, by starts,
His fretted fortunes give him hope, and fear,
Of what he has, and has not.

scene-body.stagedir: Alarum afar off, as at a sea-fight

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: All is lost;
This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me:
My fleet hath yielded to the foe; and yonder
They cast their caps up and carouse together
Like friends long lost. Triple-turn'd whore!
'tis thou
Hast sold me to this novice; and my heart
Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly;
For when I am revenged upon my charm,
I have done all. Bid them all fly; begone.
O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more:
Fortune and Antony part here; even here
Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts
That spaniel'd me at heels, to whom I gave
Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets
On blossoming Caesar; and this pine is bark'd,
That overtopp'd them all. Betray'd I am:
O this false soul of Egypt! this grave charm,--
Whose eye beck'd forth my wars, and call'd them home;
Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,--
Like a right gipsy, hath, at fast and loose,
Beguiled me to the very heart of loss.
What, Eros, Eros!
Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Why is my lord enraged against his love?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving,
And blemish Caesar's triumph. Let him take thee,
And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians:
Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot
Of all thy sex; most monster-like, be shown
For poor'st diminutives, for doits; and let
Patient Octavia plough thy visage up
With her prepared nails.
'Tis well thou'rt gone,
If it be well to live; but better 'twere
Thou fell'st into my fury, for one death
Might have prevented many. Eros, ho!
The shirt of Nessus is upon me: teach me,
Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage:
Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' the moon;
And with those hands, that grasp'd the heaviest club,
Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die:
To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall
Under this plot; she dies for't. Eros, ho!

scene-body.stagedir: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Help me, my women! O, he is more mad
Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly
Was never so emboss'd.

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: To the monument!
There lock yourself, and send him word you are dead.
The soul and body rive not more in parting
Than greatness going off.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: To the monument!
Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself;
Say, that the last I spoke was 'Antony,'
And word it, prithee, piteously: hence, Mardian,
And bring me how he takes my death.
To the monument!

scene.title: SCENE XIV. The same. Another room.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Eros, thou yet behold'st me?

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Ay, noble lord.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Sometimes we see a cloud that's dragonish;
A vapour sometime like a bear or lion,
A tower'd citadel, a pendent rock,
A forked mountain, or blue promontory
With trees upon't, that nod unto the world,
And mock our eyes with air: thou hast seen
these signs;
They are black vesper's pageants.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Ay, my lord,

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: That which is now a horse, even with a thought
The rack dislimns, and makes it indistinct,
As water is in water.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: It does, my lord.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is
Even such a body: here I am Antony:
Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
I made these wars for Egypt: and the queen,--
Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine;
Which whilst it was mine had annex'd unto't
A million more, now lost,--she, Eros, has
Pack'd cards with Caesar, and false-play'd my glory
Unto an enemy's triumph.
Nay, weep not, gentle Eros; there is left us
Ourselves to end ourselves.
O! thy vile lady!
She has robb'd me of my sword.

speech.speaker: MARDIAN
speech.line: No, Antony;
My mistress loved thee, and her fortunes mingled
With thine entirely.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Hence, saucy eunuch; peace!
She hath betray'd me and shall die the death.

speech.speaker: MARDIAN
speech.line: Death of one person can be paid but once,
And that she has discharged: what thou wouldst do
Is done unto thy hand: the last she spake
Was 'Antony! most noble Antony!'
Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
The name of Antony; it was divided
Between her heart and lips: she render'd life,
Thy name so buried in her.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Dead, then?

speech.speaker: MARDIAN
speech.line: Dead.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Unarm, Eros; the long day's task is done,
And we must sleep.
That thou depart'st hence safe,
Does pay thy labour richly; go.
Off, pluck off:
The seven-fold shield of Ajax cannot keep
The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!
Heart, once be stronger than thy continent,
Crack thy frail case! Apace, Eros, apace.
No more a soldier: bruised pieces, go;
You have been nobly borne. From me awhile.
I will o'ertake thee, Cleopatra, and
Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now
All length is torture: since the torch is out,
Lie down, and stray no farther: now all labour
Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles
Itself with strength: seal then, and all is done.
Eros!--I come, my queen:--Eros!--Stay for me:
Where souls do couch on flowers, we'll hand in hand,
And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze:
Dido and her AEneas shall want troops,
And all the haunt be ours. Come, Eros, Eros!

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: What would my lord?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Since Cleopatra died,
I have lived in such dishonour, that the gods
Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword
Quarter'd the world, and o'er green Neptune's back
With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack
The courage of a woman; less noble mind
Than she which by her death our Caesar tells
'I am conqueror of myself.' Thou art sworn, Eros,
That, when the exigent should come, which now
Is come indeed, when I should see behind me
The inevitable prosecution of
Disgrace and horror, that, on my command,
Thou then wouldst kill me: do't; the time is come:
Thou strikest not me, 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st.
Put colour in thy cheek.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: The gods withhold me!
Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,
Though enemy, lost aim, and could not?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Eros,
Wouldst thou be window'd in great Rome and see
Thy master thus with pleach'd arms, bending down
His corrigible neck, his face subdued
To penetrative shame, whilst the wheel'd seat
Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded
His baseness that ensued?

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: I would not see't.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Come, then; for with a wound I must be cured.
Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn
Most useful for thy country.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: O, sir, pardon me!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: When I did make thee free, sworest thou not then
To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once;
Or thy precedent services are all
But accidents unpurposed. Draw, and come.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Turn from me, then, that noble countenance,
Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Lo thee!

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: My sword is drawn.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Then let it do at once
The thing why thou hast drawn it.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: My dear master,
My captain, and my emperor, let me say,
Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: 'Tis said, man; and farewell.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Now, Eros.

speech.speaker: EROS
speech.line: Why, there then: thus I do escape the sorrow
Of Antony's death.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Thrice-nobler than myself!
Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what
I should, and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros
Have by their brave instruction got upon me
A nobleness in record: but I will be
A bridegroom in my death, and run into't
As to a lover's bed. Come, then; and, Eros,
Thy master dies thy scholar: to do thus
I learn'd of thee. How! not dead? not dead?
The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!

speech.speaker: First Guard
speech.line: What's the noise?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: I have done my work in, friends: O, make an end
Of what I have begun.

speech.speaker: Second Guard
speech.line: The star is fall'n.

speech.speaker: First Guard
speech.line: And time is at his period.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Alas, and woe!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Let him that loves me strike me dead.

speech.speaker: First Guard
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: Second Guard
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: Third Guard
speech.line: Nor any one.

speech.speaker: DERCETAS
speech.line: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,
Shall enter me with him.

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: Where's Antony?

speech.speaker: DERCETAS
speech.line: There, Diomed there.

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: Lives he?
Wilt thou not answer, man?

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword, and give me
Sufficing strokes for death.

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: Most absolute lord,
My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: When did she send thee?

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: Now, my lord.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Where is she?

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: Lock'd in her monument. She had a prophesying fear
Of what hath come to pass: for when she saw--
Which never shall be found--you did suspect
She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage
Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead;
But, fearing since how it might work, hath sent
Me to proclaim the truth; and I am come,
I dread, too late.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Too late, good Diomed: call my guard, I prithee.

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: What, ho, the emperor's guard! The guard, what, ho!
Come, your lord calls!

scene-body.stagedir: Enter four or five of the Guard of MARK ANTONY

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides;
'Tis the last service that I shall command you.

speech.speaker: First Guard
speech.line: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear
All your true followers out.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Most heavy day!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate
To grace it with your sorrows: bid that welcome
Which comes to punish us, and we punish it
Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up:
I have led you oft: carry me now, good friends,
And have my thanks for all.

scene.title: SCENE XV. The same. A monument.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter CLEOPATRA and her maids aloft, with CHARMIAN and IRAS

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: Be comforted, dear madam.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: No, I will not:
All strange and terrible events are welcome,
But comforts we despise; our size of sorrow,
Proportion'd to our cause, must be as great
As that which makes it.
How now! is he dead?

speech.speaker: DIOMEDES
speech.line: His death's upon him, but not dead.
Look out o' the other side your monument;
His guard have brought him thither.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter, below, MARK ANTONY, borne by the Guard

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: O sun,
Burn the great sphere thou movest in!
darkling stand
The varying shore o' the world. O Antony,
Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help;
Help, friends below; let's draw him hither.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Peace!
Not Caesar's valour hath o'erthrown Antony,
But Antony's hath triumph'd on itself.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: So it should be, that none but Antony
Should conquer Antony; but woe 'tis so!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: I am dying, Egypt, dying; only
I here importune death awhile, until
Of many thousand kisses the poor last
I lay up thy lips.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: I dare not, dear,--
Dear my lord, pardon,--I dare not,
Lest I be taken: not the imperious show
Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall
Be brooch'd with me; if knife, drugs,
serpents, have
Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe:
Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes
And still conclusion, shall acquire no honour
Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony,--
Help me, my women,--we must draw thee up:
Assist, good friends.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: O, quick, or I am gone.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!
Our strength is all gone into heaviness,
That makes the weight: had I great Juno's power,
The strong-wing'd Mercury should fetch thee up,
And set thee by Jove's side. Yet come a little,--
Wishes were ever fools,--O, come, come, come;
speech.stagedir: They heave MARK ANTONY aloft to CLEOPATRA
speech.line: And welcome, welcome! die where thou hast lived:
Quicken with kissing: had my lips that power,
Thus would I wear them out.

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: A heavy sight!

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: I am dying, Egypt, dying:
Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: No, let me speak; and let me rail so high,
That the false housewife Fortune break her wheel,
Provoked by my offence.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: One word, sweet queen:
Of Caesar seek your honour, with your safety. O!

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: They do not go together.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: Gentle, hear me:
None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: My resolution and my hands I'll trust;
None about Caesar.

speech.speaker: MARK ANTONY
speech.line: The miserable change now at my end
Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts
In feeding them with those my former fortunes
Wherein I lived, the greatest prince o' the world,
The noblest; and do now not basely die,
Not cowardly put off my helmet to
My countryman,--a Roman by a Roman
Valiantly vanquish'd. Now my spirit is going;
I can no more.

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: Noblest of men, woo't die?
Hast thou no care of me? shall I abide
In this dull world, which in thy absence is
No better than a sty? O, see, my women,
The crown o' the earth doth melt. My lord!
O, wither'd is the garland of the war,
The soldier's pole is fall'n: young boys and girls
Are level now with men; the odds is gone,
And there is nothing left remarkable
Beneath the visiting moon.

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: O, quietness, lady!

speech.speaker: IRAS
speech.line: She is dead too, our sovereign.

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: Lady!

speech.speaker: IRAS
speech.line: Madam!

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: O madam, madam, madam!

speech.speaker: IRAS
speech.line: Royal Egypt, Empress!

speech.speaker: CHARMIAN
speech.line: Peace, peace, Iras!

speech.speaker: CLEOPATRA
speech.line: No more, but e'en a woman, and commanded
By such poor passion as the maid that milks
And does the meanest chares. It were for me
To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods;
To tell them that this world did equal theirs
Till they had stol'n our jewel. All's but naught;
Patience is scottish, and impatience does
Become a dog that's mad: then is it sin
To rush into the secret house of death,
Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?
What, what! good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian!
My noble girls! Ah, women, women, look,
Our lamp is spent, it's out! Good sirs, take heart:
We'll bury him; and then, what's brave,
what's noble,
Let's do it after the high Roman fashion,
And make death proud to take us. Come, away:
This case of that huge spirit now is cold:
Ah, women, women! come; we have no friend
But resolution, and the briefest end.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt; those above bearing off MARK ANTONY's body
